metadata.case_name: Indian Steel and Wire Products Ltd. v. State of Madras

facts.text: Indian Steel and Wire Products Ltd., a joint stock public limited company, is the appellant in all appeals.
Appellant supplied certain steel products to various persons in the Madras State during financial years 1953-54, 1954-55, and part of 1955-56 from April 1, 1955 to September 6, 1955.
State of Madras assessed appellant's turnovers relating to those transactions to sales tax under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939.
Turnover for 1953-54 determined at Rs. 31,29,520/-, tax levied Rs. 16,298/4 annas.
Turnover for 1954-55 determined at Rs. 37,59,216/-, tax levied Rs. 58,737-12-0.
For broken period 1955-56, turnover determined at Rs. 14,53,292/-, tax Rs. 22,707-12-0.
Supplies made at instance of Controller under Iron & Steel (Control of Production & Distribution) Order, 1941 issued under Defence of India Act, 1939.
Iron & Steel Control Order, 1941 issued on July 26, 1941, effective August 1, 1941.
Procedure: Party desiring products applies to Controller in Calcutta; Controller processes and passes requisition to appellant for manufacture and despatch.
Appellant prepares Works Order, manufactures, delivers to Indian State Railways siding at factory in Indranagar, Jamshedpur, Bihar.
Example: K. Thiruvengadam Chetty & Co., Madras, applied to Controller on Dec 20, 1952 for M.S. rounds, 20 tons, F.O.R. Salt Cotaurs.
Controller forwarded indent to appellant for delivery in period 1/53 or subsequently.
Appellant issued Works Order RS MAD RM/15/53 dated Feb 23, 1953, to Mill Superintendent, ship to Salt Cotaurs, prices specified, subject to terms of business.
Buyers could change specifications by mutual agreement, e.g., letter Aug 31, 1953 from Thiruvengadam Chetty.
Transport by independent arrangement between appellant and buyers.
Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal found goods delivered for consumption in Madras State based on pattern of transactions, controlled distribution scheme.
High Court initially remanded for fresh finding, no new evidence, Tribunal reaffirmed.
Madras High Court judgment and order dated July 16, 1962 in Tax Cases Nos. 117,118,119 of 1959 / revisions 71-73.

legal_issues.text: Whether the transactions with which we are concerned herein are sales.
Whether there was material to show that the goods delivered by the appellant were delivered in the State of Madras for consumption.

petitioner_arguments.text: Deliveries made under compulsion of law, no agreement between parties, Controller determined persons to supply, price, transport, payment; every facet prescribed by Controller, hence not sales.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Iron & Steel Control Order, 1941; Kirkness v. John Hudson Co. Ltd.; New India Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Sales Tax, Bihar; Calcutta Electric Supply Corpn. v. CIT; Cement Ltd. v. State of Orissa

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if sales, no material to show goods delivered in Madras for consumption, hence not taxable under the Act.
Transactions effected under cl.10B of Order, no room for mutual assent.

respondent_arguments.text: Transactions are sales as elements present: competent parties, mutual assent in several respects, transfer of property, price paid.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sale of Goods Act, 1930; Sec. 2(h) Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939

respondent_arguments.text: Goods delivered for consumption in Madras State, reasonable inference from Tribunal based on controlled distribution scheme, buyers as stockists.

court_reasoning.text: To constitute sale: parties competent to contract, mutual assent, transfer of absolute property for price in money. All elements present except disputed mutual assent, but assent found in timing of supply, terms of business, payment, transport.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Controller fixed base price and buyers, but parties free to decide other terms by consent; not completely controlled.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.4 and 5 of Order empower Controller to authorize acquisition/disposal; cl.10B limited to stocked goods, not manufacturing; room for negotiation on uncontrolled matters.
Distinguished precedents: Kirkness (compulsory acquisition), New India Sugar Mills (no room for assent), others similar as compulsory transfers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Facts differ; here mutual assent present.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal finding that goods for consumption in Madras reasonable: controlled scheme for local demand, stockists buyers, small quantities, govt depts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Burden on State met; inference from circumstances.

holdings.text: Transactions are sales within meaning of Sec.2(h) Madras GST Act and constitutional power.
Goods delivered in Madras for consumption there; assessments valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley
precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of 'sale of goods' in taxing entries; must follow Sale of Goods Act meaning: agreement, assent, property transfer for price.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kirkness v. John Hudson Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Compulsory acquisition not sale due to no mutual assent; unlike here.

precedents_cited.case_name: New India Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Sales Tax, Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Sugar Control Order transactions no sales as no mutual assent; facts differ.

precedents_cited.case_name: Calcutta Electric Supply Corpn. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal
Cement Ltd. v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Cement Control Order compulsory transfers not sales.

precedents_cited.case_name: North Adjai Coal Co. P. Ltd. v. Commercial Tax Officer
S.K. Roy v. Additional Member, Board of Revenue, West Bengal

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines 'sale' broadly; covers transactions as transfers for consideration.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: State power to tax sales or purchase of goods.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Pari materia with constitutional entry; 'sale of goods' per Sale of Goods Act.

statutes_cited.name: Iron & Steel (Control of Production & Distribution) Order, 1941
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates acquisition/disposal; does not eliminate mutual assent in transactions.

statutes_cited.name: Sale of Goods Act, 1930
statutes_cited.relevance: Elements of sale: competent parties, mutual assent, property transfer for price.

outcome.summary: Appeals by special leave dismissed; High Court order upheld; transactions held to be sales with delivery for consumption in Madras State; sales tax assessments valid.

key_quotes.text: Thus, according to the law both of England and of India, in order to constitute a sale it is necessary that there should be an agreement between the parties for the purpose of transferring title to goods... Unless all these elements are present, there can be no sale.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines essential elements of a sale per Gannon Dunkerley.

key_quotes.text: My Lords, in my opinion the company's wagons, were not sold, and it would be a grave misuse of language, to say that they were sold... Alike in the ordinary use of language and in its legal concept a sale connotes the mutual assent of two parties.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quote from Kirkness distinguishing compulsory acquisition.

key_quotes.text: It would be incorrect to contend that because law imposes some restrictions on freedom to contract, there is no contract at all. So long as mutual assent is not completely excluded in any dealing, in law it is a contract.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's view on controlled transactions still being contracts/sales.
